items.title: Large contribution of antecedent climate to ecosystem productivity anomalies during extreme events
Engineering properties of expansive soil stabilized with barley husk ash and lime: case study of Jimma town subgrade soils
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 21 November 2025

Engineering properties of expansive soil stabilized with barley husk ash and lime: case study of Jimma town subgrade soils
                    Alemu Balcha1, Mohammed Hassen1, Anteneh Geremew1 & …Giza Teshome1 Show authors

Scientific Reports

volume 15, Article number: 41267 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Civil engineeringClimate-change mitigation

AbstractExpansive soils are a prevalent issue in road construction, particularly in regions like Ethiopia. They pose significant challenges due to drastic shrink-swell behavior. Traditional stabilizers such as cement and lime are effective but costly and raise environmental concerns. This necessitates exploring more sustainable, locally-sourced alternatives. This research explores using Barley Husk Ash (BHA), an agricultural byproduct, as a pozzolanic additive to stabilize expansive soil from Jimma, Ethiopia. The untreated soil had an initial PI of 39% and a CBR of 0.8%. The study had two phases. First, optimal lime content was determined by treating the soil with varying lime percentages (0–20%) in 5% increments. Second, this lime content was combined with BHA in similar 5% increments (0–20%). Adding 10% lime reduced the PI to 22%, increased the CBR to 9.72%, and raised the Unconfined Compressive Strength (UCS) to 137 kPa. This met the Ethiopian Roads Authority (ERA) S4 subgrade standard (CBR>5%). Adding 10% BHA to the 10% lime-stabilized soil further improved performance. The PI dropped to 18% and the CBR increased to 18.42%, qualifying the soil for the higher S5 subgrade classification (CBR 15%-30%). Microstructural analysis using SEM confirmed these findings. The BHA-lime blend created a denser, more cohesive soil matrix with enhanced inter-particle cementitious bonding. This explains the improved strength and reduced swell potential. The mean porosity also decreased from 17.33% to 6.74%. This research validates a 10% lime plus 10% BHA blend as a highly effective, sustainable, and locally available solution for modern road construction.

IntroductionThe subgrade, a compacted or natural soil layer, is foundational to pavement structures. Its stability and strength are crucial for overall performance and durability. While pavement design often emphasizes surface materials, it is important to recognize that subgrade quality heavily influences the pavement’s ability to withstand traffic loads and environmental stresses1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9. An understanding of subgrade behavior is especially critical when dealing with problematic soil types.Expansive soils present significant challenges to subgrade performance worldwide. These soils expand and contract as moisture levels change, resulting in cracks, unstable foundations, and road failures10,11. Their particle configuration, which is plate-like in morphology and high in surface area, leads to extreme shrink–swell behavior. These soils can take up water, causing 10–30% or more volumetric expansion, and then a decrease in volume as they dry12,13,14. Ikeagwuani and Nwonu15 noted that the high susceptibility to volumetric changes and moisture inherent in these clays has caused extensive damage to structures. The soils concerned usually exhibit an extremely high degree of plasticity; for instance, black cotton clays usually have liquid limits of more than 60% and plasticity indices of more than 30%, thus qualifying as high-plasticity clays (USCS CH)16.Tanyildizi et al.17 state that expansive soils are susceptible to volume change with variations in moisture content, which causes serious damage to light structures, particularly road pavements. They note that a black cotton clay with LL ≈ 68% and PI ≈ 34% is classified as a CH clay with high swelling potential. Grain size distribution and cation exchange capacity (CEC) are also determined since finer-grained clays with high CEC retain more pore water and show more shrink-swell behavior.In the case of roads, these movements cause wavy roads, and in the case of structures, they cause foundation cracks and tilting. Control of moisture (e.g., by drainage or moisture barriers) is a significant design concern to prevent uncontrollable ground movement18,19. However, flexible pavements deteriorate prematurely due to issues such as rutting, raveling, stripping, and cracking. The long-term performance and durability of highways largely depend on the characteristics of the subgrade layer, which serves as the foundation support for the pavement system20.The importance of improving and safely utilizing expansive soils has grown significantly. Soil stabilization is the process of treating soil to enhance its strength and reliability. This technique can be applied to various soil types, including clay and sandy soils. By stabilizing the soil, we can increase its resistance to changes, reduce water absorption, and decrease the softness that can lead to problems. These enhancements allow for thinner road surfaces, making roads more durable and cost-effective. Overall, this process contributes to the construction of better and longer-lasting roads21,22,23,24,40,41,42,43,44.There are a few common methods for stabilizing expansive soils. One method is mechanical stabilization, which involves enhancing the soil’s strength and performance using physical techniques without the addition of chemicals. This approach helps create a more stable foundation for construction and other uses25. Several techniques can be employed to strengthen and stabilize soil. One such technique is compaction, which involves pressing the soil down to make it denser. Another method is pre-loading or pre-wetting, which prepares the ground in advance to improve its stability. If the soil is unsuitable, it can be replaced or mixed with better materials, such as gravel. Properly compacted soil, especially when maintained at the optimum moisture level, becomes denser and has fewer voids, helping to prevent future issues like swelling26,27.In various situations, researchers may also use chemical methods to stabilize soil28. Chemical stabilizers alter the chemistry and microstructure of the soil to reduce plasticity and clump particles together29,30. Common conventional stabilizers include lime, cement, and fly ash, all of which contain calcium31. In practice, mechanical compaction or moisture conditioning is usually practiced in conjunction with chemical stabilization for optimal results. Traditional stabilization methods use lime and cement, which undergo chemical reactions with the soil to improve its strength and durability. A very useful stabilizer for expansive clay soil is lime. The released calcium ions (Ca2+) engage in exchange with monovalent cations on the surface of clay particles (e.g., sodium ions, Na+) because of the cation exchange capacity inherent in the clay32,33. Furthermore, quicklime (CaO) reacts exothermically with water to form calcium hydroxide (Ca(OH)2), raising porewater pH to>~12.4. At the same time, high pH dissolves silica and alumina from clay minerals; these mobilized species then react with Ca(OH)2 in pozzolanic reactions to form cementitious calcium silicate and aluminate hydrates34.Portland cement, for example, is a hydraulic binder that consolidates soil rapidly, but its manufacture is extremely energy and carbon-intensive (one ton of cement will emit~0.8–0.9 tons of CO2). A study by Mustafayeva et al.35 shows that cement contributes approximately 7% of the world’s CO2 emissions, a very real problem in sustainable construction. Lime production also requires high-temperature kilns, adding to the embodied carbon. Apart from greenhouse gas emissions, large-scale use of cement or lime increases the expense and can also bring about sulphate-related issues. In the presence of soil sulphates, lime can form ettringite and gypsum, which causes secondary expansion (the so-called soil lime sulphate reaction)36,37. Moisture control by subjecting the subgrade to alternating cycles of saturation and drying can be detrimental even to lime-stabilized subgrades, as empirical practice has witnessed variable performance in regions with monsoonal climatic regimes35. However, cost and environmental concerns associated with these materials have prompted investigation of other, locally sourced materials and greener alternatives38,39.Recent research trends highlight the importance of locally available sustainable stabilizers. Different studies examine the utilization of by-products from industrial and agricultural sources to minimize the use of Portland cement and natural lime35. Innovative methods, including the use of bamboo charcoal, quarry dust, zeolitic tuff, Probase SH-85, and TX-85, have been found to enhance the characteristics of expansive soils for use in road subgrades. For example, fly ash (a coal combustion residue), granulated blast-furnace slag, and steel slag provide reactive silica/alumina and calcium. It can be activated by alkalis or lime to produce cementitious binders. It is limited by the low Ca content when alone, but with lime addition, it gives a high pozzolanic reaction that improves strength gain16. Tanyildizi et al.17 found that the fly ash-lime blend not only improved subgrade strength but also utilized waste material (reduced landfill mass). Likewise, various other by-products such as marble or granite powder, eggshell ash, and ground furnace slag have been utilized as admixture material for lime or cement14.Agricultural residues are also promising in construction. Sawdust ash, rice husk ash, and sugarcane bagasse ash contain silica and are being tested as partial cement replacements. Experimental results show that adding sawdust ash to expansive clay can significantly reduce plasticity and increase strength35. Moreover, because agricultural waste is readily available in large quantities, it offers a cost-effective and environmentally friendly option, making it a promising alternative for soil stabilization. Due to these different reasons, the utilization of waste material for soil stabilization is viewed in a positive light, as it has the potential to enhance the load-bearing capacity of the soil, the shear strength, and minimize its permeability. This approach promotes sustainability and can significantly improve daily travel for local communities45,46,47.While previous research has examined agricultural byproducts for soil stabilization, the present study introduces a novel approach utilizing locally sourced Barley Husk Ash (BHA). This method improves soil stabilization efficiency and advances sustainability, establishing BHA as a viable alternative for enhancing soil quality. Barley is cultivated on approximately 70 million hectares worldwide, with global production reaching 160 million tons. Developing countries account for around 18% of total barley production, contributing about 26 million tons, and 25% of the total harvested area, which is approximately 18.5 million hectares. The primary uses of barley grain are as animal feed, malt, and human food. Additionally, farmers in regions such as West Asia, North Africa, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Yemen, the Andes, and East Asia use barley straw as animal feed48. Africa produced 6–8 million tons, with Ethiopia leading at 2.1–2.5 million tons on 1 million hectares, yielding 1.9–2.2 tons per hectare49,50.Barley is an important cereal crop in Ethiopia, with high genetic diversity, spatial distribution across elevations, breeding progress toward superior varieties, production problems and opportunities, and a wide range of uses in food, feed, and industry50. In 2012, Assela Malt Factory expanded its production capacity from 22,000 to 36,000 tons to meet the growing demand for processed malt barley, an agricultural byproduct of the brewing industry in Ethiopia. The facility requires 500,000 quintals (or 50,000 tonnes) of high-quality raw malt barley to produce 360,000 quintals (or 36,000 tonnes) of malt per year51. Barley husk is abundantly produced in Ethiopia52 and its husks are readily available for reuse in the construction industry. As a result, the use of indigenous resources for subgrade soil stabilization is essential. In this study, BHA was mixed with lime to examine its performance when combined with the optimal amount of lime utilized for stabilization. The evaluation of BHA as a solution for enhancing subgrade soil stabilization when combined with lime reveals its significant potential to not only improve the effectiveness of conventional stabilizers but also to serve as a viable alternative. This innovative approach could lead to more efficient and sustainable practices in soil stabilization.Materials and methodsMaterialsExpansive soil: Soil samples were collected from different locations in Jimma town, such as Shenen Gibe, Kochi, and Kito.Barley Husk Ash (BHA): Barley husk was collected from Arsi Zone, Assela town (Assela Malt Factory), which is a high-potential area in Barley crop production.Lime: Lime was purchased from suppliers in Jimma.Research designThe study utilized a laboratory experimental design to assess the stabilization of expansive soil using lime and Barley Husk Ash (BHA) for subgrade construction. Several laboratory studies have investigated the stabilization of expansive soils using lime combined with agricultural ashes, particularly rice husk ash (RHA), as a partial analog to barley husk ash (BHA). These studies typically use varying lime contents (3–10%) and RHA proportions (4–20%) to determine optimal mixtures for improving engineering properties such as unconfined compressive strength (UCS), California Bearing Ratio (CBR), and durability53,54,55,56. In the case of this study, lime was applied at (5%, 10%, 15%, and 20%) by dry weight of soil to determine the optimal content. Subsequently, the optimal lime content was combined with varying BHA proportions (5%, 10%, 15%, and 20%) to evaluate improvements in engineering properties. Barley husk ash has not been directly investigated for its potential to stabilize expansive soils. The percentage used in this study is specific to its findings. BHA, like rice husk ash (RHA), is rich in amorphous silica. When added to lime-treated soil, it supplies extra silica for pozzolanic reactions, allowing continued formation of cementitious compounds (calcium silicate hydrates, C-S-H) that further strengthen and densify the soil matrix57,58. The calcium hydroxide (Ca(OH)2) produced from lime reacts with the amorphous silica in BHA to form additional C-S-H and calcium aluminate hydrates (C-A-H), which are responsible for increased strength, reduced plasticity, and improved durability59,60. Furthermore, the study examined the effects of partially replacing lime with BHA at equivalent ratios. Laboratory tests, including Atterberg limits, compaction, unconfined compressive strength, California Bearing Ratio (CBR), and other tests, were conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of the stabilization treatments. The overall research work is outlined in Fig. 1.Fig. 1Research design flowchart.Full size imageLaboratory testsChemical composition test for expansive soil, BHA, and limeThe chemical composition of natural expansive soil, Barley Husk Ash (BHA), and lime is detailed in Table 1. The characteristics of these chemical compositions significantly influence their potential applications in fields such as construction and soil stabilization. BHA, an industrial byproduct from barley processing, has garnered interest for its promising uses in construction and agriculture, primarily due to its unique chemical makeup. The BHA sample under study contains high levels of silicon dioxide (SiO2) at 40.54%, potassium oxide (K2O) at 18.4%, phosphorus pentoxide (P2O5) at 11.5%, and aluminum oxide (Al2O3) at 5.86%. These components are crucial in assessing the potential of BHA as a pozzolanic material and soil stabilizer. The elevated levels of SiO2 and Al2O3 in BHA indicate its pozzolanic properties. When pozzolanic materials come into contact with calcium hydroxide and water, they form compounds that exhibit cementitious characteristics.Table 1 Chemical composition of test materials.Full size tableAli et al.61 examined the blending of BHA with OPC and established that the replacement of OPC by 15% with BHA enhanced the compressive strength by 42% after 28 days of curing. This improvement is due to the pozzolanic reactions caused by the silica and alumina present in BHA. Likewise, research on various agricultural ashes, for example, rice husk ash (RHA), has revealed that their high silica content is largely responsible for the development of the mechanical properties of cement-based systems62. Lime, which contains 67.2% calcium oxide (CaO), is commonly used for soil stabilization. Mixing with soil and water causes cation exchange, flocculation, and pozzolanic reactions, which harden the soil and reduce its plasticity. These reactions enhance the engineering qualities of soils, and thus, lime is a valuable additive in construction works, especially in clayey soils63.Natural soil analysis reveals a high level of silica (SiO2) at 82.86%, which is typical for silty or sandy soils. Moderate mineralization is also indicated by the presence of aluminum oxide (Al2O3) at 4.12% and iron oxide (Fe2O3) at 3.78%. The comparatively low percentages of calcium oxide (CaO) at 0.98% and magnesium oxide (MgO) at 0.46% suggest low natural fertility and potential acidity. Soils in areas such as Ethiopia tend to have such characteristics, needing stabilization in construction.In conclusion, the presence of high silica and nutrients in BHA renders it applicable for use in construction and agricultural sectors. The calcium-rich nature of the lime is significant in stabilizing soil, thereby improving structural strength in the construction sector. Additionally, the mixture of BHA and lime can enable the production of calcium silicate hydrates, thereby improving stabilized soil strength and durability.Natural soil gradation testSieve analysis is a method of determining the particle size distribution of a given material. The test procedure was conducted according to AASHTO T8866 specifications. For particles larger than sieve No. 200, a wet sieve analysis was employed, and for those particles passing through sieve No. 200, a hydrometer analysis was performed according to ASTM D792867. Figure 2 shows the results of the sieve analysis conducted on the natural soil examined in this research.Fig. 2Natural soil particle size distribution.Full size imageAtterberg LimitThe Atterberg limit test is used to determine the critical water content of fine-grained soils, helping classify their behavior under varying moisture conditions. These limits are essential in geotechnical engineering for soil classification and for assessing properties such as compressibility, shear strength, and shrink-swell behavior68.The test was conducted according to the AASHTO T-89-9069 standard, using a 0.425mm pass sample. The results of the Atterberg limit test for natural soil samples from Shenen Gibe, Kochi, and Kito indicate high plasticity, making them unsuitable for subgrade construction without modification (Table 2). According to the Ethiopian Roads Authority (ERA) Pavement Design Manual, a plasticity index (PI) exceeding 30 is considered poor for subgrade material70. Specifically, the Shenen Gibe sample exhibited a PI of 39%, Kochi 39%, and Kito 35%, all surpassing the ERA’s threshold. Such high PI values suggest that these soils possess significant clay content, leading to undesirable characteristics like high compressibility and expansive behavior, which can adversely affect the stability and durability of pavement structures71.Table 2 Natural soil Atterberg limit results.Full size tableCompaction testThe compaction test is conducted to determine the optimum moisture content and maximum dry density of soil, which are essential for assessing its suitability for construction. In this study, the test was performed using the Standard Proctor method (AASHTO T-99)72. A soil sample passing a 4.75mm sieve was used for the test. The results help evaluate the soil’s compaction characteristics and its ability to achieve desired strength and stability in engineering applications.California Bearing Ratio (CBR) testThe California Bearing Ratio (CBR) test evaluates the strength of pavement subgrade, subbase, and base materials. The sample preparation involves compacting soil specimens in a mold at a specified density and moisture content, often determined by AASHTO T-99. The test procedure involves soaking the specimen, applying a load with a penetration piston at a rate of 1.25 mm/min, and recording the penetration resistance values. The standard used is AASHTO T-19373 to ensure consistency in pavement design.Unconfined compressive strength testThe Unconfined Compressive Strength (UCS) test determines the shear strength of cohesive soils without lateral confinement74. The preparation of samples involves trimming undisturbed soil specimens or compacting remolded samples to standard dimensions, while ensuring consistent moisture content. The test procedure includes placing the specimen in a compression machine and applying axial load at a controlled strain rate (typically 1.27 mm/min) until failure occurs. The standard used is ASTM D216675, which provides guidelines for testing cohesive soils in undisturbed, remolded, or compacted conditions.Free swell and specific gravityThe Free Swell Index (FSI) test determines the swelling potential of expansive soils when submerged in water. The sample preparation involves taking two 10g oven-dried soil specimens (passing through a 425-micron sieve) and placing them in two 100 ml graduated cylinders, one filled with kerosene and the other with distilled water. The test procedure requires allowing the soil to settle for at least 24 h, after which the final volumes are recorded. The Free Swell Index (%) is calculated as Eq. (1).$${\text{FSI}} = \left[ {\left( {{\text{Vd}} - {\text{Vk}}} \right)/{\text{Vk}}} \right] \times {1}00$$
                    (1)
                where Vd is the volume in water and Vk in kerosene.The free swell index of Shenen Gibe, Kochi, and Kito are 109%, 100%, and 91%, respectively (Table 3).Table 3 Laboratory test results of natural soil samples.Full size tableThe Specific Gravity test adheres to ASTM D85476 and utilizes a pycnometer or density bottle to measure the ratio of soil particle density to the density of water. The preparation of the sample involves drying the soil, removing any trapped air, and thoroughly mixing it with water. During the test procedure, the soil is weighed under three different conditions: when dry, when submerged, and within the pycnometer. This allows for the calculation of its specific gravity. The specific gravities of Shenen Gibe, Kochi, and Kito are 2.63, 2.60, and 2.67, respectively.Classification of the soil samplesAccording to the AASHTO soil classification system (AASHTO M145)77, all soil samples fall under A-7-5 (Table 4). It indicates that they are made up of highly plastic silt and clay material. This type of soil is known for its poor drainage and its potential for significant expansion. In the USCS soil classification system, these samples fall into the CH category, which stands for Fat Clay. Which means they possess high plasticity, low strength, and exhibit notable shrink-swell behavior. Given these characteristics, it’s clear that the soil needs stabilization for construction purposes, especially for improving subgrades in roads and foundations.Table 4 AASHTO soil classification of the Shenen Gibe soil sample.Full size tableTable 3 shows the engineering properties of natural soil, indicating variations in compaction, strength, and stability. Shenen Gibe has the highest MDD (1.417 g/cm3) and lowest OMC (23.5%), while Kito requires more moisture for effective compaction (OMC=28.6%). CBR values range from 10.79% (Kito) to 14.64% (Shenen Gibe), with low CBR swell (0.8%–1.3%, free swell of 109), suggesting moderate expansion potential. UCS results show Kochi has the highest strength (82 kPa) and Shenen Gibe has the lowest (65 kPa). Shenen Gibe and Kochi soils are highly plastic (PI=39%), with Shenen Gibe having the weakest bearing capacity (CBR=0.8% and a highly free swell index), making it unsuitable for direct use. This study aims to identify the engineering properties of natural soils from three areas and select the most expansive one. Shenen Gibe soil was selected for stabilization with lime and Barley Husk Ash (BHA) because of its low strength and high plasticity. Therefore, this study focuses on it as it urgently needs a solution.Microstructural test for natural soil, lime, and barley husk ash (BHA)Microstructural analysis investigates the internal structure and composition of materials to understand their physical and chemical interactions. In soil stabilization, this analysis helps identify the formation of cementitious compounds and the densification of the soil matrix resulting from the addition of lime and BHA. The test was performed as per ASTM C1723-10, which guides examining hardened concrete using Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM)78.Specimens of natural soil, lime, and BHA, as well as their mixtures, were prepared at the desired proportions. Then the specimen was cured under controlled conditions (e.g., 7, 14, and 28 days) to allow pozzolanic reactions to occur. After curing, oven-dry the samples at 40 °C to 60 °C to remove moisture without altering mineral structures. Mount small fragments on aluminum stubs using conductive carbon tape and sputter-coat them with a thin layer of gold or platinum to prevent charging during SEM examination. Utilize SEM to capture high-resolution images of the sample surfaces, revealing morphological features and particle arrangements.Results and discussionEffect of lime on natural expansive soilEffect of lime on the Atterberg limit of soilThe Atterberg limits (LL, PL, and PI) define the consistency and plasticity of fine-grained soils. Table 5 indicates that the Liquid Limit, Plastic Limit, and Plasticity Index decrease from 72 to 45%, 33% to 29%, and 39% to 16%, respectively, as the lime content increases from 0 to 20% in 5% increments. Studies have shown that lime stabilization significantly reduces PI, improving soil workability and reducing expansion risks79.Table 5 Summary of the effect of lime on natural expansive soil.Full size tableEffect of lime on specific gravityThe specific gravity of soil solids (Gs) is a crucial parameter in geotechnical engineering, reflecting the density of soil particles relative to water. For natural expansive soils, a specific gravity of 2.63 is within the typical range for clay soils, which generally spans from 2.60 to 2.8080. Upon lime stabilization, the specific gravity of expansive soil decreases, as observed from 2.63 to 2.57, with a 20% lime content, as shown in Table 5. This reduction indicates chemical alterations in the soil minerals due to lime treatment, leading to increased void ratios and changes in soil structure. The decrease in specific gravity with increasing lime content underscores the impact of lime on soil properties, influencing compaction behavior and overall soil stability. Similar findings suggest that lime-treated soils exhibit lower specific gravity due to increased void ratios63.Effect of lime on free swell index (FSI)The data presented in Table 5 and Fig. 3 indicate a significant reduction in the free swell index (FSI) of expansive soil with increasing lime content. Specifically, the FSI decreased from 109 to 33% upon the addition of 20% lime, marking a 70% improvement. This substantial decrease underscores the efficacy of lime stabilization in mitigating the swelling and shrinkage potential of expansive soils.Fig. 3Effect of lime on FSI.Full size imageThe reduction in FSI can be attributed to the chemical interactions between lime and the clay minerals present in the soil. Lime induces cation exchange, flocculation, and pozzolanic reactions, forming stable compounds that diminish the soil’s affinity for water. Consequently, the soil’s volumetric changes due to moisture variations are significantly reduced.A study by Salih and Mohammed Shafiqu81 demonstrated that adding 9% lime to expansive soil reduced the swelling potential from 18.77% to 6.03%. These findings corroborate the effectiveness of lime in enhancing the dimensional stability of expansive soils. However, it’s essential to note that the optimal lime content for stabilization varies depending on soil characteristics. Excessive lime addition may not yield proportional benefits and could potentially lead to adverse effects82. Therefore, determining the appropriate lime percentage through testing is crucial for achieving the desired soil improvement.Effect of lime on compaction characteristicsTable 5 and Fig. 4 show that initially, the addition of lime (up to 10%) to expansive soil results in a slight decrease in OMC from 23.5% to 23.0%. This reduction can be attributed to the immediate reaction between lime and soil moisture, leading to the formation of calcium hydroxide and the flocculation of clay particles, which reduces the soil’s water-holding capacity.Fig. 4Effect of lime on compaction characteristics.Full size imageHowever, with further lime addition (15% and 20%), OMC increases to 24.0% and 24.5%, respectively. This increase is due to the pozzolanic reactions that occur over time, forming cementitious compounds that require additional water for the chemical processes. Additionally, the flocculated and agglomerated soil structure resulting from higher lime content increases the void spaces, necessitating more water to achieve optimal compaction. This trend is consistent with findings from other studies, which found that increasing lime content leads to higher OMC due to the increased moisture demand of the altered soil structure16.The MDD shows a slight increase with 5% and 10% lime addition, from 1.417 g/cm3 to 1.423 g/cm3. This increase is likely due to the initial flocculation and agglomeration of clay particles, which enhances particle packing and compaction efficiency. Beyond 10% lime content, MDD decreases to 1.413 g/cm3 and 1.408 g/cm3 for 15% and 20% lime addition, respectively. The reduction in maximum dry density (MDD) at higher lime contents can be explained by the development of a more open and porous soil structure. This occurs as clay particles flocculate and cementitious compounds form, taking up more space and resulting in a decrease in overall density. This observation aligns with previous research indicating that higher lime content leads to a decrease in MDD due to the increased void ratio and lower specific gravity of lime compared to soil particles16,83.California Bearing Ratio (CBR)As indicated in Table 5 and Fig. 5, laboratory tests revealed that the California Bearing Ratio (CBR) of the natural expansive soil is 1.27%. This value falls short of the Ethiopian Roads Authority (ERA) 2013 Pavement Design Manual’s minimum requirement for subgrade construction, which stipulates a CBR value greater than 5% for subgrade class S4. Therefore, the expansive soil requires improvement before it can be used effectively in road construction70.Fig. 5Effect of lime on CBR value @95% MDD and CBR swell.Full size imageTo enhance the soil’s properties, a soaked CBR test was conducted to assess the impact of lime stabilization. The results demonstrated that the CBR value increased with the addition of lime, peaking at a certain point before declining with higher lime contents. Specifically, adding 5% lime increased the CBR to 6.51%, and 10% lime raised it further to 9.72%. However, increasing the lime content to 15% and 20% resulted in decreased CBR values of 9.13% and 6.98%, respectively. This decline is due to the reduction of soil volume, as lime fills the pores, resulting in decreased penetration resistance. Consequently, the optimal lime content for stabilizing the soil is determined to be 10%, achieving an improvement of approximately 665% in CBR value compared to the untreated soil. These findings align with previous studies. For instance, a study on the Wozeka-Gidole road project in Arbaminch, Ethiopia, demonstrated that using 8% lime as a stabilizer resulted in a 90.7% increase in strength, significantly enhancing the soil’s suitability for subgrade applications84.The California Bearing Ratio (CBR) swell percentage is a crucial indicator of the swelling potential of expansive soils, which can significantly impact the stability of structures built upon them. Data indicates that untreated natural expansive soil (NES) exhibits a high CBR swell of 14.64%. However, when stabilized with increasing percentages of lime, there’s a notable reduction in swell potential: 11.94% at 5% lime, 9.4% at 10% lime, 8.7% at 15% lime, and 7.12% at 20% lime. This result underscores the efficacy of lime stabilization in mitigating the swelling behavior of expansive soils. The reduction in swell is attributed to chemical reactions between lime and clay minerals, leading to the formation of cementitious compounds that enhance soil strength and reduce plasticity. Such improvements are essential for ensuring the durability and reliability of infrastructures, especially in regions prone to soil expansion and contraction45,85,86.Unconfined Compressive StrengthTable 5 and Fig. 6 illustrate the outcomes of unconfined compressive strength (UCS) tests conducted on natural soil samples treated with varying percentages of lime. The tests were conducted immediately (0 days) and after a curing period of 7 days. For the untreated natural soil, the initial cohesion value was measured at 65 kPa. Upon the addition of 5% lime, the cohesion increased to 120 kPa in the immediate test, indicating a significant enhancement. However, further increases in lime content beyond 5% resulted in a gradual decrease in cohesion values.Fig. 6Effect of lime on the unconfined compressive strength (UCS) value.Full size imageAfter a 7-day curing period, the UCS results demonstrated a continued improvement in cohesion: 124 kPa for 5% lime addition and 137 kPa for 10% lime addition. Beyond the 10% lime content, a decline in cohesion was observed. These findings suggest that a 10% lime content is optimal for enhancing soil strength, achieving a 111% improvement in UCS compared to untreated soil.These findings are in line with earlier research on using lime to stabilize soil. For example, one study looked at a type of soil called loess and found that adding more lime increased its strength up to a certain point. After reaching this ideal level, adding more lime made it weaker87. Similarly, other research on clay soils with low plasticity showed that strength improved significantly with more lime until it hit a peak percentage. Beyond that, the benefits of adding more lime started to decrease88.The observed strength improvements can be attributed to the chemical reactions between lime and soil minerals. Initially, cation exchange and flocculation-agglomeration processes occur, enhancing the soil’s structure. Over time, pozzolanic reactions between calcium ions from lime and silica or alumina in the soil form cementitious compounds like calcium-silicate-hydrates (C–S–H), further increasing strength63.Microstructures of study materials and lime effectTo assess the microstructural changes induced by lime stabilization, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analyses were performed on untreated expansive soil and a mixture comprising 10% lime and 90% expansive soil. Figure 7 indicates the SEM Micrographs captured at magnifications of 10 µm×3000 and 50 µm×600 of expansive soil, lime, and barley husk ash. The results show that as the magnification increases, the number of pore areas and porosity increase, but the size of pore areas decreases. Figure 8 shows that the mean pore area of lime, expansive soil, and BHA is 34.49, 43.62, and 73.51, respectively, at×3000 SEM magnification. Similarly, Fig. 9 shows that the average porosity of lime, expansive soil, and BHA is 9.95%, 17.33%, and 10.24%, respectively, at×3000 SEM magnification.Fig. 7SEM of expansive soil (a), Lime (b), and BHA (c and d).Full size imageFig. 8Pore area analysis of individual material under the SEM.Full size imageFig. 9Porosity analysis of individual material under the SEM.Full size imageFigure 10 illustrates that the soil treated with 10% lime exhibits a denser and more compact microstructure with reduced void spaces compared to the untreated sample. This densification indicates enhanced soil properties, as the lime treatment improves particle bonding and reduces an average pore area to 24.74, as shown in Fig. 11 at×3000 SEM magnification. The results show that the pore size of expansive decreased by 43.3%.Fig. 10SEM image of expansive soil treated with 10% lime at×600 (a) and×3000 (b) magnification.Full size imageFig. 11Pore area analysis of expansive soil treated with 10% lime under the SEM.Full size imageThese observations align with findings from previous studies. Research on lime-stabilized silt clay demonstrated that lime addition leads to the formation of cementitious gels, resulting in a denser microstructure and improved geotechnical properties. Similarly, a study on lime-stabilized clay highlights that SEM analyses showed a more compact and less porous structure in treated samples, correlating with increased strength and stability89,90. The enhancement in soil density and reduction in voids due to lime stabilization can be attributed to several mechanisms.Flocculation and Agglomeration: Lime induces the aggregation of clay particles, leading to a more stable soil structure. Lime reacts with silica and alumina in the soil over time to form cementitious compounds, such as calcium-silicate-hydrate (C–S–H), which fill voids and bind particles together.Reduction in Plasticity: Lime treatment decreases the plasticity of clay soils, contributing to improved workability and strength91.Figure 12 illustrates the porosity analysis of lime-treated expansive soil (10% lime+90% expansive soil), revealing distinct scale-dependent behavior. The mean porosity decreases from 12.05% at the 10 μm×3000 scale to 7.14% at the 50 μm×600 scale. This 41% reduction indicates that lime treatment is more effective at stabilizing larger pore structures than finer voids, likely due to the preferential formation of cementitious bonds that bridge macropores and fill interaggregate spaces. The higher standard deviation observed at 10 μm×3000 (25.11) compared to 50 μm×600 (16.64) reveals greater microscale heterogeneity, suggesting incomplete reactions at particle contacts and localized high-porosity zones.Fig. 12Porosity analysis of expansive soil treated with 10% lime under the SEM.Full size imageNotably, maximum porosity values of 100% at 10 μm versus 91.29% at 50 μm confirm that lime significantly reduces microporosity. For geotechnical applications requiring further reduction in porosity, extended curing periods, increased lime content, or complementary stabilization methods (e.g., compaction or fiber reinforcement) could be considered. The results underscore the value of multi-scale porosity analysis in soil stabilization, as it reveals treatment efficacy across the critical pore-size spectrum that governs expansive soil behavior92.Effect of BHA on engineering and physical properties of soilEffect of BHA on Atterberg limitTo evaluate the impact of Barley Husk Ash (BHA) on the Atterberg limits of expansive soil treated with the optimal lime content, a series of laboratory tests was conducted. The results, summarized in Table 6, indicate that incorporating BHA into lime-stabilized soil significantly alters its consistency characteristics.Table 6 Effect of Barley Husk Ash (BHA) on soil engineering properties.Full size tableLiquid Limit (LL): The addition of BHA led to a reduction in the liquid limit of the soil. Specifically, the LL decreased from 52% with 0% BHA to 47% with 20% BHA. This decrease suggests a reduction in the soil’s water-holding capacity, which can be attributed to the pozzolanic reactions between the silica-rich BHA and the calcium from lime, resulting in the formation of cementitious compounds that bind soil particles more effectively. Similar findings were examined by Dauda and Dominic93, observed that combining BHA with lime reduced the LL of expansive soils, enhancing their stability.Plastic Limit (PL): An increase in the plastic limit was observed with higher BHA content. The PL rose from 30% at 0% BHA to 33% at 20% BHA. This increase indicates that the soil requires more moisture to reach a plastic state, which is beneficial in reducing its susceptibility to deformation under load. The enhancement in PL can be linked to the improved soil structure due to the flocculation and agglomeration of clay particles facilitated by the lime-BHA interaction.Plasticity Index (PI): The PI, defined as the difference between LL and PL, decreased from 21 to 14% as BHA content increased to 20%. This 36% reduction in PI signifies a substantial decrease in the soil’s plasticity, indicating improved dimensional stability and reduced potential for swelling and shrinkage94. These improvements align with the observations that the addition of BHA to lime-treated soils effectively reduced PI, enhancing the soil’s engineering properties93. In summary, the incorporation of BHA into lime-stabilized expansive soils leads to a decrease in LL and PI while increasing PL.Effect of BHA on specific gravityTable 6 shows the impact of Barley Husk Ash (BHA) on the specific gravity of expansive soil stabilized with the optimal lime content (10%). The initial specific gravity of the lime-treated soil was measured at 2.59. As the amount of BHA increased, the specific gravity values showed a consistent decrease: 2.42, 2.25, 2.03, and 1.93 for BHA contents of 5%, 10%, 15%, and 20%, respectively.This downward trend indicates that BHA possesses a significantly lower specific gravity compared to the expansive soil. The reduction in specific gravity can be attributed to the replacement of denser soil particles with the lighter BHA particles. Such behavior is consistent with findings from previous studies, which have highlighted that the incorporation of BHA into soil matrices leads to a decrease in specific gravity due to the lower density of BHA particles61,95.In conclusion, the addition of BHA to lime-stabilized expansive soils results in a notable reduction in specific gravity, primarily due to the lower density of BHA compared to the native soil particles. This characteristic can influence other geotechnical properties of the soil, such as compaction behavior and strength parameters, and should be considered when designing soil stabilization strategies.Effect of BHA on free swell indexTo evaluate the impact of Barley Husk Ash (BHA) on the swelling behavior of expansive soil stabilized with the optimal lime content (10%), a series of free swell index (FSI) tests was conducted. The soil–lime mixtures were amended with varying BHA contents: 0%, 5%, 10%, 15%, and 20%. The results, depicted in Fig. 13, indicate a progressive decrease in FSI with increasing BHA content. Notably, the addition of 20% BHA resulted in a 40% reduction in FSI compared to the mixture without BHA.Fig. 13Effect of BHA on free swell index.Full size imageThis reduction in swelling potential can be attributed to the pozzolanic reactions between the silica-rich BHA and the calcium from lime, leading to the formation of cementitious compounds that bind soil particles more effectively. Such behavior is consistent with findings from previous studies, which have noted that the incorporation of agricultural ashes into lime-stabilized soils leads to a decrease in FSI due to the formation of stable soil structures96.In conclusion, the incorporation of BHA into lime-stabilized expansive soils effectively reduces the free swell index, indicating improved dimensional stability and reduced potential for swelling and shrinkage. This enhancement in soil behavior underscores the potential of BHA as a sustainable additive in geotechnical applications.Effect of BHA on Compaction TestAs depicted in Table 6 and Fig. 14, increasing the Barley Husk Ash (BHA) content in soil mixtures results in a continuous rise in moisture content from 23% at 0% BHA to 29.4% at 20% BHA. Simultaneously, the Maximum Dry Density (MDD) decreases from 1.422 g/cm3 to 1.22 g/cm3. This trend indicates that BHA contributes to higher moisture retention and lower dry density in the soil97.Fig. 14Effects of BHA on compaction characteristics.Full size imageSimilar patterns have been observed with other agricultural ashes. For instance, studies on Rice Husk Ash (RHA) have shown that increasing RHA content leads to a decrease in MDD and an increase in OMC98. This is due to the porous and lightweight nature of RHA, which absorbs more water and requires higher moisture content for compaction. Additionally, the pozzolanic reactions between RHA, lime, and soil minerals consume water, further increasing the soil’s OMC99. These findings underscore the potential of using agricultural waste products like BHA and RHA for soil stabilization, particularly in road construction projects. Their incorporation can enhance soil properties by increasing moisture content and reducing dry density, leading to more stable and durable subgrade layers.The addition of lime and BHA influences the soil’s workability and particle aggregation (flocculation-agglomeration), which in turn affects the Optimum Moisture Content (OMC) and Maximum Dry Density (MDD). A change in OMC and MDD upon stabilization indicates the modification of the soil’s structure and moisture-density relationship due to physicochemical reactions. Proper compaction ensures adequate strength, stiffness, and reduced compressibility, which are vital for the constructability and long-term performance of stabilized layers in roadbeds, embankments, and foundations100,101,102,103.Effect of BHA on California Bearing Ratio (CBR)Table 6 and Fig. 15 illustrate that increasing Barley Husk Ash (BHA) content in lime-stabilized expansive soils initially enhances the California Bearing Ratio (CBR), reaching a peak at 10% BHA, beyond which further addition leads to a decline. This improvement is attributed to pozzolanic reactions between the silica-rich BHA and calcium hydroxide (Ca(OH)2) from lime and soil, forming cementitious compounds that strengthen the soil matrix.Fig. 15Effect of BHA on CBR and CBR swell.Full size imageThe maximum soaked CBR value recorded was 18.42% at optimal lime content with 10% BHA, marking an 89.5% increase over lime-treated soil. According to the Ethiopian Roads Authority (ERA) Pavement Design Manual70, a subgrade with a CBR of 18.42% falls into Subgrade Class S5, which encompasses CBR values ranging from 15 to 30%. Soils in this class are considered to have good bearing capacity, allowing for reduced pavement thickness and, consequently, lower construction costs.A similar finding by Aluga et al.39 observed that adding 9% BHA to natural soil increased the CBR from 38 to 80%, highlighting the efficacy of BHA in enhancing soil strength. Stabilization with lime and BHA significantly increases CBR values by creating a more rigid and interlocking matrix through cation exchange, flocculation-agglomeration, and primarily, pozzolanic reactions. The formation of C-S-H and C-A-H gels binds the soil particles together, enhancing load-bearing capacity. CBR is a fundamental parameter in pavement design, specifically for determining the thickness requirements of subgrades, sub-bases, and base courses. Higher CBR values allow for thinner pavement layers, leading to cost savings and improved pavement life104,105,106.As the Barley Husk Ash (BHA) content increases in a lime-stabilized expansive soil matrix, the CBR swell percentage decreases significantly from 9.72% to 3.66%. This progressive reduction in CBR swell percentage with increasing BHA content suggests enhanced volumetric stability of the soil. The underlying mechanism can be attributed to the pozzolanic reactions between the silica-rich BHA and the calcium hydroxide from lime, leading to the formation of cementitious compounds such as calcium silicate hydrates (CSH) and calcium aluminate hydrates (CAH)107. These compounds bind soil particles together, reducing their affinity for water and thereby diminishing swelling potential.Such behavior aligns with findings from previous studies. Research has shown that adding pozzolanic materials, such as bagasse ash, to lime-stabilized soils reduces swelling characteristics by forming stable cementitious matrices that limit moisture ingress46. In conclusion, the incorporation of BHA into lime-stabilized expansive soils effectively reduces the CBR swell percentage, enhancing the material’s suitability for subgrade applications.Effect of BHA on unconfined compressive strength (UCS)Table 6 and Fig. 16 show that the Unconfined Compressive Strength (UCS) of the soil decreases with increasing Barley Husk Ash (BHA) content for both immediate (0-day) and 7-day curing periods. For the 0-day test results, the cohesion (C) of the soil decreased from 63 kPa at the optimum lime content to 30 kPa, 47 kPa, 27 kPa, and 32 kPa for 5%, 10%, 15%, and 20% BHA content, respectively. Similarly, for the 7-day test results, cohesion (C) decreased from 137 kPa at the optimum lime content to 117 kPa, 101 kPa, 88 kPa, and 66 kPa for the same respective BHA contents. This consistent decline in UCS with increasing BHA content can be attributed to the lower calcium oxide composition in BHA, which is essential for the pozzolanic reactions that contribute to soil strength.Fig. 16Effects of BHA on unconfined compressive strength (UCS).Full size imageThese findings align with previous studies. Research has shown that while husk ashes can enhance certain soil properties, their effectiveness diminishes at higher concentrations due to their lower calcium content compared to lime108. In one study, the UCS of soil increased with rice husk ash (RHA) content up to an optimal point, beyond which further addition led to a decrease in strength109. Pushpakumara and Mendis57 observed that the addition of RHA beyond 10% resulted in a reduction of UCS, emphasizing the importance of determining an optimal husk ash content for soil stabilization. Azam et al.110 found that Soil with 10% vege grout (rotten vegetable) showed the highest percent increase in UCS of 192% increment, followed by 5% of vege grout with 156% increment within the first three weeks of curing. On the other hand, a higher amount of vege grout in treated soil results in very low strength at early curing time.Furthermore, Gidebo et al.45 utilized a variety of agricultural waste materials, such as rice, wheat, sugarcane, and bamboo ash, for the stabilization of expansive soil. Their study further confirmed that agricultural waste additives could be a better replacement for the expensive and resource-intensive soil-stabilization techniques with less technical skills, as well as cheaper local materials. The expansive soil stabilized with agricultural waste additives has shown significant improvements in terms of strength development, compressibility, and reduction in cracking111. In conclusion, while BHA can be beneficial in soil stabilization, its content must be carefully optimized. Excessive BHA can lead to reduced UCS due to insufficient calcium oxide for effective pozzolanic reactions. These microstructural changes contribute to enhanced mechanical properties of the stabilized soil, including increased strength and reduced permeability, as the denser matrix limits water ingress and improves load-bearing capacity. In contrast, the BHA-lime blend forms a denser, more homogeneous matrix with smaller, evenly distributed pores, suggesting enhanced particle bonding.At the microscopic level (×3000), lime alone shows partial clay particle coating and uneven cementation, while the BHA-lime combination demonstrates thorough particle encapsulation and more uniform pozzolanic reaction products. The superior microstructural development in the BHA-lime blend correlates with improved engineering properties, including reduced swell potential and higher shear strength.Statistical analysisTable 7 shows the statistical analysis (mean and standard deviation) of the soil parameter test results, and they are summarized as follow:Table 7 Statistical analysis of soil parameters.Full size tableThe Atterberg limits: Liquid Limit (LL), Plastic Limit (PL), and Plasticity Index (PI)—show a mean of 52.6%, 30.9%, and 21.7%, respectively, with standard deviations of 8.0%, 1.4%, and 7.2%. The relatively low variation in PL indicates high repeatability and consistency in that test, while the higher deviation in LL and PI suggests moderate variability. This narrow spread supports the uniform influence of lightweight additives such as Barley husk ash (BHA.For the compaction test, the Maximum Dry Density (MDD) and Optimum Moisture Content (OMC) have mean values of 1.36 g/cm3 and 25.3%, with standard deviations of 0.07 and 2.19, respectively. However, this variability is still within expected ranges.The CBR swell (mean = 8.21%, SD = 3.45%) and Free Swell Index (FSI) (mean = 46.11%, SD=25.11%) show reductions, indicating improved soil behavior, though the FSI’s high standard deviation suggests low repeatability and high variability in expansive behavior. This is often observed in soils with varying clay mineralogy and stabilizer interaction.The Unconfined Compressive Strength (UCS) shows a mean of 94.67 kPa and a standard deviation of 28.37 kPa. This reflects significant strength gain with moderate variability, suggesting that while the test results are reasonably reliable, they are influenced by mix proportion and curing quality.ConclusionThis study demonstrates the successful stabilization of problematic expansive soil from Jimma, Ethiopia, using a dual-additive approach of lime and Barley Husk Ash (BHA). The research established that an optimal mix of 10% lime and 10% BHA significantly enhances the soil’s engineering properties. Key findings indicate a substantial reduction in plasticity by 70% and swell potential, alongside a notable increase in the California Bearing Ratio (CBR) by 2202.5%, elevating the soil to a higher subgrade classification suitable for road construction.The significance of this research lies in its validation of a sustainable and locally sourced agricultural byproduct as a viable alternative to conventional, costly, and carbon-intensive stabilizers. The synergistic effect of the BHA-lime blend creates a denser, more cohesive soil microstructure, improving its mechanical properties. While the Unconfined Compressive Strength (UCS) of the dual-additive mix was slightly lower than that of soil treated with lime alone. The substantial improvements in CBR and plasticity present a strategic trade-off, particularly for low to medium-traffic roads where sustainability and cost-effectiveness are paramount.This method has significant potential for geotechnical and civil engineering applications, particularly in Ethiopia and other regions with similar agricultural conditions. Utilizing an abundant agricultural byproduct, it provides a sustainable, cost-effective alternative for building resilient infrastructure, reducing dependence on conventional, high-cost, high-carbon stabilizers. This research offers concrete technical evidence for national road authorities to amend construction specifications and include BHA as an accepted stabilizer. Such a policy would promote a circular economy, cut costs for rural and regional road projects, and support national sustainability goals.Recommendations for future research
                
                  Long-Term Performance Studies: Investigate the long-term durability and strength development of lime BHA stabilized soils under various curing conditions and exposure to environmental factors (e.g., wet-dry cycles, Freeze-Thaw (F-T) Cycles and Sulfate Exposure).
                
              Future studies on stabilized soil will focus on three key durability tests to assess long-term performance under various environmental stressors. First, wetting-drying (W-D) cycles will be conducted according to ASTM D559 (12 or 24 cycles). Performance will be evaluated based on retained Unconfined Compressive Strength (UCS) and mass loss. Acceptable criteria are a minimum of 80% retained UCS and a maximum of 5% mass loss. Second, freeze-thaw (F-T) cycles will simulate cold region effects, following ASTM D560 (12 or 24 cycles). Evaluation will focus on retained UCS and visual integrity, with similar criteria as the W-D test to prevent significant deterioration. Finally, sulfate resistance will be tested by immersing samples in a 5% sodium sulfate (Na2SO4) solution for 28, 56, 90, and 180 days. Changes in UCS, pH, and visual appearance such as swelling or cracking will be monitored. Success will be defined by minimal strength loss and no significant swelling or cracking. To capture the full extent of long-term pozzolanic reactions, curing periods for these durability tests will be extended up to 90 or 180 days, beyond the current 7-day period.
                
                  Economic Viability Assessment: Perform a comprehensive cost–benefit analysis comparing lime-BHA stabilization with traditional methods in the Ethiopian context, considering BHA collection, processing, and transportation costs.
                
                
                  Optimization of BHA Production: Explore the effect of controlled incineration temperatures and durations for BHA production on its potential pozzolanic activity and stabilization effectiveness.
                
                
                  Field Trials: Conduct pilot field trials to validate the laboratory findings and assess the practical applicability and performance of lime-BHA stabilized subgrades under actual traffic and environmental loads.
                
                
                  Exploration of other Local Wastes: Extend similar research to other locally abundant agricultural or industrial wastes in Ethiopia that could serve as soil stabilizers.

Data availability
              
              All data used to support the findings of the study are included in the article.

items.title: Pesca artigianale, l’Italia accelera sul Piano d’Azione Regionale FAO-CGPM
items.description:
Si è svolta oggi presso il MASAF la tavola rotonda dedicata all’attuazione in Italia del piano CGPM/FAO con stakeholder e istituzioni
The post Pesca a
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie Si è svolta oggi, presso il Ministero dell’Agricoltura, della Sovranità alimentare e delle Foreste (MASAF), la tavola rotonda “Verso l’implementazione del Piano d’azione regionale FAO-CGPM per la pesca artigianale”, un momento di confronto tra istituzioni, cooperative della pesca artigianale, Aree Marine Protette, mondo pesca, mondo della ricerca e organizzazioni non governative, dedicato all’attuazione in Italia del piano promosso dalla Commissione Generale per la Pesca nel Mediterraneo e nel Mar Nero (CGPM/FAO). Un impegno politico di portata storica Il Piano RPOA-SSF, sottoscritto come Dichiarazione ministeriale nel settembre 2018 dai rappresentanti dei Paesi del Mediterraneo e del Mar Nero e dell’Unione europea (Italia inclusa), rappresenta un impegno politico di portata storica. Costituisce una road map decennale (2018–2028) volta a garantire la sostenibilità ambientale, economica e sociale della pesca artigianale, adattando al contesto mediterraneo le Direttive volontarie della FAO per la piccola pesca. “La piccola pesca come risorsa strategica” Aprendo i lavori, moderati dal vicepresidente Medac Giampaolo Buonfiglio, Marco Lupo, Capo Dipartimento del MASAF per le politiche competitive, della qualità agroalimentare e l’ippica, ha sottolineato come la piccola pesca rappresenti un settore che merita di essere sostenuto con strumenti concreti, partecipazione e visione a lungo termine. Nel suo intervento, il Sottosegretario di Stato, Patrizio La Pietra, ha sottolineato che “la piccola pesca artigianale rappresenta una risorsa strategica per il Paese. Il MASAF è pronto a proseguire il  confronto con tutti gli attori coinvolti per sostenere il settore della piccola pesca.” Nel corso della mattinata, esperti e stakeholder hanno discusso le principali sfide per il settore – dal ricambio generazionale alla redditività, fino alla necessità di una governance più inclusiva basata su dati esaustivi e capillari – condividendo esperienze e proposte per costruire un percorso nazionale condiviso di attuazione del Piano. Come ricordato da Anna Carlson, Fishery Officer della CGPM/FAO, “Il successo del RPOA-SSF dipende dalla capacità dei Paesi di trasformare i principi in azioni concrete, coinvolgendo tutti gli attori – dai pescatori alle istituzioni – in un dialogo continuo e costruttivo.” La gallery della tavola rotonda al MASAV “Un alleato prezioso per la tutela del mare” Come evidenziato da Alessandra Prampolini, direttrice generale del WWF Italia,  “la pesca artigianale sostenibile è un alleato prezioso per la tutela del mare e per il benessere delle comunità costiere. L’attuazione del Piano in Italia è un passo necessario per unire conservazione, innovazione e giustizia sociale, mettendo le persone e gli ecosistemi al centro delle politiche marittime.” L’Alleanza delle Cooperative Italiane Pesca (Confcooperative Fedagripesca, Agci Pesca e Acquacoltura, Legacoop Agroalimentare) ha ribadito che “la piccola pesca non è solo una componente economica, ma un patrimonio culturale e sociale che va tutelato e valorizzato. Il Piano rappresenta un’occasione concreta per rafforzare il ruolo dei pescatori nella gestione sostenibile delle risorse e nella costruzione di un futuro condiviso per le comunità costiere. Il modello italiano di piccola pesca già esiste ed è quello elaborato in questi anni dall’Alleanza delle Cooperative. Tale modello merita di diventare il punto di riferimento nazionale, di essere fortemente finanziato per una sua implementazione nazionale e disseminato in tutto il Mediterraneo.” Le cinque priorità Dalla giornata di confronto sono emerse cinque priorità operative per accelerare l’attuazione del Piano in Italia. Istituire momenti di approfondimento regolari, anche utilizzando e ampliando i meccanismi istituzionali già esistenti  per garantire un confronto strutturato e inclusivo tra istituzioni, settore, ricerca e società civile.Definire un quadro normativo nazionale per la cogestione, capace di supportare lo sviluppo di piani di gestione locali partecipati, fornendo regole chiare.Allocare risorse dedicate e strumenti finanziari stabili per monitoraggio, formazione e innovazione, anche alla luce dei cambiamenti nella programmazione europea.Rafforzare la raccolta e condivisione dei dati sulla piccola pesca, integrando conoscenze scientifiche e tradizionali per decisioni basate su evidenze.Valorizzare e replicare le buone pratiche già esistenti, così da costruire un modello italiano di pesca artigianale sostenibile. I partecipanti hanno espresso una volontà comune a portare avanti questi obiettivi, riconoscendoli come elementi essenziali per rafforzare la resilienza della piccola pesca e contribuire alla sostenibilità del Mediterraneo. Lucio Biancatelli 18 Aprile 2017 La guida WWF per un consumo sostenibile di pesce Circa il 30% degli stock ittici del Pianeta è sovrasfruttato e che oltre il 60% è pescato al limite delle capacità biologiche. Consumare in modo sostenibile e consapevole è possibile: facendo la scelta giusta i consumatori possono contribuire… Nicole Brogna 18 Aprile 2020 La tutela degli oceani passa attraverso il nostro piatto “Siamo tutti sulla stessa barca”: quante volte abbiamo sentito pronunciare questa frase in questo periodo?   Su questa grande barca che è la natura, poggiamo tutti i piedi, e se c’è qualcosa che possiamo evitare per danneggiare gli ecosistemi,… Lucio Biancatelli 8 Agosto 2020 Il WWF promuove il turismo marino a supporto della piccola pesca Nel quadro di un anno difficile, che ha avuto ripercussioni gravissime per la piccola pesca in Italia, è fondamentale saper cogliere le opportunità che il contesto di crisi offre e sfruttarle per creare una rete di supporto alle… 7 Giugno 2024 GenerAzioneMare del WWF per salvare il Capitale Blu Con centinaia di attivisti tra volontari, ricercatori, pescatori, subacquei, prende il via la fase estiva della Campagna OurNature

items.title: Forum Agroecologia: le tredici proposte di Legambiente e i nuovi Ambasciatori premiati
items.description: Tra le richieste stanziare le risorse per il PNACC, attuare il PAN, sostegni alle aree marginali, sviluppo dell’agrivoltaico, una legge per fermare i
items.body:
20 Novembre 2025

Legambiente

20 Novembre 2025

Comunicati stampa

Agricoltura , Crisi climatica

Forum Agroecologia: le tredici proposte di Legambiente e i nuovi Ambasciatori premiati

20 Novembre 2025

Legambiente

20 Novembre 2025

Comunicati stampa

Agricoltura , Crisi climatica

Tra le richieste stanziare le risorse per il PNACC, attuare il PAN, sostegni alle aree marginali, sviluppo dell’agrivoltaico, una legge per fermare il consumo di suolo, le agromafie e l’agropirateria,  una PAC coraggiosa che premi la qualità, più biologico nelle mense pubbliche.

L’agricoltura è il grande oro dell’Italia. Eppure, è sempre più a rischio e fragile, schiacciata da scelte politiche miopi e dagli effetti della crisi climatica. È quanto denuncia Legambiente che oggi al VII Forum nazionale sull’agroecologia circolare, fa un punto su “contrappesi e pesi” del comparto agricolo, indirizzando all’Europa e all’Italia tredici proposte che hanno al centro la bussola dell’agroecologia. I dati parlano chiaro: nel 2024, stando ai dati ISTAT, l’agricoltura italiana ha conquistato il primato europeo per valore aggiunto, superando i 42 miliardi di euro (+9% rispetto al 2023). A contribuire al valore del settore agroalimentare ci sono 583 prodotti DOP (Denominazione di Origine Protetta) e 266 prodotti IGP (Indicazione Geografica Protetta), per un totale di 853 prodotti agroalimentari. Nella Penisola cresce il biologico: stando agli ultimi dati disponibili Sinab 2024, il bio rappresenta ormai oltre il 20% della SAU nazionale, vicino al target del 25% previsto dal Green Deal europeo al 2030. Sempre più giovani decidono, inoltre, di lavorare nel comparto agricolo puntando su qualità e sostenibilità, a testimoniarlo anche gli oltre 200 Ambasciatori dell’Agroecologia, di cui 11 nel 2025, premiati in questi anni da Legambiente. Numeri e storie che ben raccontano un settore strategico per il Paese, che però si trova a fare i conti anche con numerose difficoltà e dove la strada che viene indicata è il più delle volte quella della quantità e non della qualità.   
PESI e RITARDI: A pesare sull’agricoltura, ci sono gli effetti della crisi climatica ma anche un modello di gestione intensivo e poco sostenibile. Siccità e alluvioni, spostamenti degli areali colturali e perdita di produttività stanno ridisegnando la geografia agricola italiana. Gli studi scientifici confermano che diverse colture tipiche mediterranee stanno già subendo stress termici e spostando le zone di vocazionalità verso Nord e verso altitudini maggiori. Sul fronte zootecnico, le importazioni di foraggi e mangimi dall’estero – soprattutto soia e mais – restano eccessivamente elevate. Pesano i ritardi nel ridurre i carichi emissivi e la densità dei capi, nel promuovere il benessere animale e una dieta verso un minor consumo di carne, privilegiando la qualità al posto della quantità. Sull’agricoltura pesano anche le scelte politiche miopi: per Legambiente preoccupano le recenti misure del pacchetto semplificazioni e gli indirizzi della nuova PAC che hanno come obiettivo non dichiarato l’indebolimento degli standard ambientali in ambito agricolo e in materia di uso dei pesticidi, aprendo alla possibilità di deroghe per l’impiego di sostanze non autorizzate. Così come a livello nazionale pesano i ritardi sulla mancata attuazione del PNACC, ad oggi mancano le risorse per attuare il piano nazionale di adattamento ai cambiamenti climatici che include anche misure anche per l’agricoltura, e quella del PAN (Piano d’Azione Nazionale) sull’uso sostenibile dei fitosanitari la cui ultima stesura risale al 2014.  
Aziende medie piccole in sofferenza: Intanto negli ultimi 38 anni sono scomparse due aziende su tre e la dimensione media è più che raddoppiata, aprendo la strada a una forte concentrazione fondiaria (dati ISTAT). In questo scenario, Legambiente ricorda che l’80% delle risorse PAC continua a finire al 20% delle aziende, mentre su 100 euro spesi dal consumatore solo 1,5 euro arrivano all’agricoltore (ISMEA). È così che interi territori — in particolare quelli collinari e montani — si spopolano, perdendo presidi agricoli e ambientali cruciali, lasciando spazio all’abbandono ed al dissesto idrogeologico.  
13 proposte all’Europa e all’Italia: Di fronte a questo quadro, Legambiente indirizza oggi tredici proposte, otto all’Italia e cinque all’Europa. Al Governo Meloni Legambiente chiede: 1) lo stanziamento delle risorse per attuare il PNACC in agricoltura; 2) l’approvazione di una legge nazionale per fermare il consumo di suolo; 3) Un piano strutturale per sostenere le imprese agricole e zootecniche delle aree interne e montane; 4) Un piano nazionale per il biologico e per la ristorazione collettiva, con misure volte a sostenere il settore, colmare il significativo divario tra domanda e offerta, fornire  incentivi per le mense pubbliche biologiche, sgravi fiscali e una riduzione dell’IVA sui prodotti bio, accompagnato da una strategia incisiva per moltiplicare i biodistretti da Nord a Sud. 5) Un piano per sviluppare agrivoltaico e biometano di qualità definendo regole chiare, iter autorizzativi capaci di rispondere in tempi adeguati alle urgenze poste dalla sfida climatica, criteri ambientali rigorosi e incentivi premianti per quei progetti agricoli che aumentano resilienza, reddito e tutela del suolo. 6) l’approvazione di una legge sulle agromafie e l’agropirateria, intensificando i controlli sullo sfruttamento e sul caporalato in agricoltura e introdurre norme specifiche contro i pesticidi illegali, rafforzando controlli, tracciabilità e sanzioni lungo l’intera filiera. 7) Attuare in modo immediato e rafforzato il PAN (Piano d’Azione Nazionale) sull’uso sostenibile dei prodotti fitosanitari — la cui ultima stesura risale al 2014 — prevedendo obiettivi vincolanti, monitoraggi capillari e strumenti di accompagnamento per le aziende agricole. Obiettivo: raggiungere il -50% di pesticidi entro il 2030, come indicato dalla strategia europea Farm to Fork. 8) approvare al più presto il DPR sul riutilizzo delle acque reflue depurate in agricoltura. 
All’Europa l’associazione ambientalista chiede di: 1) rimettere al centro del Green Deal Europeo le strategie europee Farm to Fork e Biodiversity 2030; 2) definire una nuova PAC che premi davvero la qualità e le buone pratiche per l’ambiente ed il clima, abbandonando una logica basata sulla quantità e su modelli intensivi che impoveriscono territori e redditi; 3) mettere in campo un “Blue Deal” europeo per l’acqua con investimenti e regole comuni per promuovere colture meno idroesigenti, pratiche colturali come rotazione e consociazione per contrastare la monocoltura, il ripristino della fertilità dei suoli, tecniche di irrigazione efficienti, infrastrutture verdi, il riutilizzo delle risorse idriche e il sostegno all’adattamento degli areali agricoli. 4) Avviare un percorso europeo di uscita dal glifosato — il cui utilizzo, nonostante i comprovati effetti negativi sugli ecosistemi e sulla nostra salute, è stato prorogato per altri dieci anni, mentre alternative sostenibili come l’acido pelargonico continuano a incontrare grandi difficoltà autorizzative — e dai neonicotinoidi, dannosi non solo per l’uomo ma anche per gli insetti impollinatori. 5) Così come serve una norma europea più severa e vincolante sul multiresiduo — ovvero la presenza simultanea, nello stesso alimento, di più residui di pesticidi diversi, che possono interagire tra loro amplificando gli effetti sulla salute e sugli ecosistemi — accompagnata da limiti più cautelativi e da un piano obbligatorio di monitoraggio trasparente in tutti i Paesi membri. 
“L’unica strada per garantire resilienza, qualità, sostenibilità, competitività e futuro all’agricoltura italiana – commenta Stefano Ciafani, presidente nazionale di Legambiente – è quella dell’agroecologia. L’Europa e l’Italia partano da questo caposaldo, ricordando che conciliare agricoltura e transizione energetica è possibile. Agrivoltaico e biometano se ben progettati rappresentano una leva decisiva per rafforzare il reddito aziendale, aumentare la capacità di adattamento climatico ed evitare le gravi perdite produttive dei raccolti. Il governo modifichi l’articolo 5 del Decreto Agricoltura che vieta il fotovoltaico a terra, anche dove potrebbe essere utilizzato come i terreni inquinati o che non sono mai stati produttivi, e approvi al più presto una legge contro il consumo di suolo che il Paese attende da troppi anni. È inaccettabile, infatti, che nuovi investimenti su poli logistici, data center, autostrade, aree residenziali o produttive continuino, indisturbati, a consumare suolo agricolo, che, contrariamente a quanto succederebbe coi pannelli fotovoltaici, perderemmo in modo permanente”.  
“L’agricoltura italiana – dichiara Angelo Gentili, responsabile nazionale agricoltura di Legambiente – o sceglie con coraggio la strada dell’agroecologia oppure continuerà a rincorrere un modello intensivo che negli ultimi decenni ha prodotto impoverimento dei territori, crollo del reddito agricolo e vulnerabilità crescente di fronte alla crisi climatica. Al Governo Meloni e all’Europa chiediamo scelte lungimiranti per abbinare al made in Italy l’agroecologia ed essere più capaci di rispondere alla sfida climatica e più competitivi, a partire da una nuova PAC coraggiosa, che premi la qualità e non la quantità e che sia coerente con gli obiettivi delle strategie europee Farm to Fork, Biodiversity 2030 e del Green Deal. Occorre inoltre promuovere la qualità e la sostenibilità delle filiere agroalimentari e frenare agricoltura e zootecnia intensive, accelerare il ripristino di norme ambiziose sulla riduzione dei pesticidi, pianificare investimenti nelle aree interne e marginali, nelle misure agroecologiche e nel biologico”. 
Premio Ambasciatori dell’Agroecologia 2025: Legambiente ha premiato oggi 11 Ambasciatori dell’Agroecologia, il riconoscimento che assegna a quelle realtà agricole che incarnano in modo esemplare i principi dell’agroecologia, della tutela della biodiversità, dell’innovazione sociale e della cura dei territori. In Umbria, BUBO Social Farm trasforma orti biologici e fattorie didattiche in strumenti di inclusione, grazie a percorsi di ortoterapia e attività con gli animali per le persone fragili. Un approccio sociale che trova un’eco in Puglia con la cooperativa Qualcosa di Diverso, impegnata a rigenerare 50 ettari confiscati alla criminalità organizzata attraverso agroecologia, lavoro comunitario e produzioni biologiche. L’agricoltura rigenerativa guida le scelte di diverse aziende: in Campania Tenuta Principe Mazzacane alleva capre cilentane e produce formaggi biologici in equilibrio con agrobiodiversità e benessere animale; in Toscana Fattoria Triboli unisce olivicoltura, pascolo razionale, biofertilizzanti e un’importante attività educativa; nelle Marche Nevola Naturae combina colture biologiche, vigneti recuperati e progetti per le scuole, sostenendo il valore delle aree interne. Tradizione, innovazione e gestione sostenibile caratterizzano invece la Azienda Agricola Bio Ferrarini in Emilia-Romagna, impegnata in un’agricoltura biologica e biodinamica che migliora la fertilità del suolo; Tenuta Morganti in Abruzzo, guidata da due sorelle under 30, e dove vigneti, ulivi, bosco, lago e apiario formano un ecosistema integrato alimentato a energia solare; e l’Azienda Agricola Radica in Calabria, che coltiva mele autoctone e piante officinali, senza diserbanti e tecniche di agricoltura sostenibile. Il valore educativo e la tutela della biodiversità emergono anche nel Lazio con il progetto Macerbe di Arianna Salvi che ad Amatrice riporta l’attenzione sulle erbe spontanee come strumenti di rinascita, riscoprendo il valore del paesaggio naturale; e in Veneto con S’Infiora Fattoria Bio che produce miele biologico e propone percorsi educativi sulla vita delle api e sull’importanza degli ecosistemi. Infine, in Molise, Agrialba dove la produzione di formaggi a latte crudo, olio da varietà locali, galline all’aperto, orto rigenerativo, conserve biologiche e autonomia energetica convivono con attività educative come Alba Experience e la Scuola Rurale.  
Il VII Forum Agroecologia Circolare di Legambiente rappresenta una tappa del percorso associativo volto a promuovere un Clean Industrial Deal Made in Italy. 
 
Partner principali: BF Energy, Fileni, COPROB-Italia Zuccheri, Renexia 
Partner sostenitore: CIB 
Partner: Almaverde Bio, Apo Conerpo, Blunova, Caviro, Coop Italia, Ecomondo, Rigoni di Asiago, Qualità e Servizi 
Media partner: Nuova ecologia e AzzeroCO2

On January 27, 2025, clumps of solidified vegetable oil were found along a 25 km stretch of coastline on Finland’s Hanko Peninsula. While not toxic, the substance posed risks to wildlife. Suspecting it came from a passing vessel’s cargo tank wash, Finnish authorities launched an investigation,…

The COSNORTH-SEMAR DSS is a decision-support system developed to enhance maritime surveillance and law enforcement along Spain’s northern coast. Created in collaboration with the Guardia Civil, it combines environmental data, vessel tracking, and predictive modeling in a user-friendly platform…

Planning a sailing route based on weather used to be hard and needed expert skills. Many sailors didn’t use it because it was too complicated. SailRouting changes that by offering an easy online tool that shows weather-based routes in just a few clicks — no setup needed.

With SailRouting…
